reviews.content: I am somewhat guilty of neglecting Deanston so far, and I am not even sure why. To me, it has always been the least interesting distillery in the Distell portfolio. On the nose, apple pie, honeydew melon and lemongrass mingle with malty and cereal-rich notes. Nothing sticks out, but it is quite pleasant. Spicy and drying flavors surprise on the palate before it mellows with juicy fruits, peppery oak and a touch of cider. A few drops of water help. Orange zest, honey and lingering spices migrate into the savory and floral finish. I am certainly not disappointed.RATING: 3.5/5.0 stars ≙ 84 pts → ABOVE AVERAGE

reviews.content: https://whiskylovingpianist.wordpress.com/2024/11/01/brighton-whisky-club-angels-share/C: Perhaps sweeter and certainly more sherried than I’ve found it in the past [WLP185 WLP286 WLP387 WLP483], I’m impressed once again. Must get myself another bottle, it’s been too long. It remains fairly priced too.

https://whiskylovingpianist.wordpress.com/2023/08/02/bottle-polishing-a-summer-pair/Having previously enjoyed this permashelf bottling on a number of occasions [WLP185 WLP286 WLP387], another bottle was inevitable.N: In five words, wood, banana, cream > plantain > omelette. Of the woodiness, we are talking of a clean & clear/active first-fill bourbon influence, so confectionary vanilla is also a given. A Scotch for bourbon fans, perhaps? As this open bottle enters its second year, the egginess lifts, largely to be replaced by a far more pleasing maltiness – and a fusty maltiness at that. It’s at the heel of the bottle that things begin to sing. A touch of honeysuckle, rose apple, and the like, provide some bonus top notes.T: More than halfway down the bottle, unfortunately, this less than pleasing slightly eggy gacky/edgy/resinous bourbon-derived, [mahogany] woody profile persists. Compared to earlier releases, I ask myself – where’s the sweet banana, where’s the toffee, where are the nuances? Again, It took two years for this bottle to open up and chill out a little. Well into year two, we’ve a transition towards a sweeter maltier direction after a persistent active wood spice explosion. Though the citric woody spiciness endures, additional water will bring out a few of the nuances I was looking/hoping for.F: Gacky/filmy sour/bitter ex-bourbon wood for the large part. Things are far more desirable at the heel of the bottle, creamy if green maltiness the main improver, though overall, it remains immediate even lightly insipid.C: What a difference two years makes. I had this at a dislikable 80 for a fair while. Thankfully, a sour-to-sweet evolution in the bottle came through with the casks softening almost enough. A tad full-on – cask-wise – for my liking, but it’s a fine line. A very decent malt but other versions have been more to my liking.

https://whiskylovingpianist.wordpress.com/2019/04/03/whiskylive-2019-day-1-part-2/After TBWC stand, I’d no specific plans. Brian Houston from Deanston catches my eye so I decide to refresh my memory of Deanston’s new-found excellence after a distillery visit there in 2017 [blog].C: The 18yo shares a similar pleasing profile to the 12yo with something lost & something gained – plenty gained actually. Both crackers! Both score 87 points

https://whiskylovingpianist.wordpress.com/2017/08/01/deanston-from-mill-to-distillery-part-2/N: Oily barley, cereal-fruits, dusty flour, a little clay, bitter-sweet oils and fruity biscuit notes – less banana more raisins. Solid & simple complexity.T: Oily barley again with a bitter oily/molasses edge. Nice & clean, [oily clean] bitter oily chew. Water brings to the fore more cereal sweetness and another touch of clay with that prevalent bitter molasses note – bitter-sweet all the way.F: Waxy-dry molasses.C: Bitter-sweet fruity oily barley spirit with raisins over bananas – what’s not to like? I’m amazed how faithful the spirit is to the airborne smells of the distillery. Big improvements over previous decades. During my three week distillery trip, this was the only bottle i bought directly.Scores a B-

reviews.nose: Delicate sweetness. Quite a specific aroma. A bit of honey. Maybe some malt. Delicate skin, but very delicate. Some vanilla and caramel. A pinch of spices. White pepper. Some wood. Quite a volatile aroma. Traces of fruit underneath. On the second nose, more sweetness and more vanilla.
reviews.taste: Light sweetness. Lots of caramel. Slight bitterness. Lots of wood. Some spices. White pepper. There is a slight oiliness. Honey the second time.
reviews.finish: Spices. White pepper. Sweetness. Vanilla. Caramel. A bit of oak. Long finish. The second time there were citruses at the beginning and then a lot of honey.

reviews.nose: Sweet vanilla and light honey up front. A touch of waxiness and some cereal malt notes. Bright citrus notes and candied orange peels. Some apricot and melon with cooked pears and bananas. Overall the bourbon influence is clearly present here with a heavy oak note. I wonder if there were some recharred barrels included as well.
reviews.taste: Creamy mouthfeel. Very obvious honey and vanilla notes with barley water. Slightly bitter orange peels balance this out well with a bright tangy lemon note. Cooked apples now. A touch of black pepper warmth and some drying wood tannins. At 12 years of age, I think some rather active casks were used here as the oak influence is quite pronounced.
reviews.finish: More of the same from the palate here. Slightly more black pepper spice but all the oak and honeyed citrus peels come through along with more vanillins.

reviews.content: Brilliant value for money - enough complexity in this that you can come back to it again and again, finding something new. Thanks to the distillery who let the spirit shine!
reviews.nose: The spirit is well balanced with the oak.Soapy fresh lemon and hints of herbs (clary sage), cereal (porridge and pasta), lemon oat biscuits, oak, fresh cedar and pencil shavings, caramel, vanilla, spicy-green woody notes (fir needles and sap), hints of fruit (pear and underripe banana). Orange peel, bee pollen, ginger, pepper, blackcurrant cough drops.
reviews.taste: Sweet, then citrusy, followed by spicy-woody, finishes soft and fruity. Cereal throughout.Buttery/oily vanilla and soft oak, caramel, cereal, lemon, ginger, fir needles, cardamom, oak, banana, green pear.

reviews.content: (Bought march 2020. Bottle code 2018608 L516:5419226) Tasted 01.04.2020.APPEARANCE: Deep gold colour. Much darker than the Deanston 15 YO Organic. Quite viscous, noticeable long, slim legs on the side of the glass.NOSE: Dried fruits, mainly yellow; dried mango, dried banana. Waxy. Mineral notes, direction oils and metal, fresh engine oil. With time also some red dried fruits arrive. I think there must have been sherry or other wine casks in the mix here. A few drops of water opens it up a little more, emphasising the mineral aspect more. (88-89p)TASTE: The arrival is quite rich, red dried berry kind of fruity. On the mid palate there’s sweet barley juice (but darker than in the 15) and forest honey. With a few drops of water it becomes sweeter and full of sweet barley juice. (86-88p)FINISH: On the exit there’s barely juice with quite a bit of black pepper.... With a few drops of water it becomes sweeter. (86-87p)OVERALL: TOTAL SCORE 87 points.

(Tasted 01.03.2019)NOSE: Already straight out of the bottle, this smells nicely of serious whisky with an initial nose of malt, minerals, iodine and light smoke. Like a cousin of Springbank. After some minutes the smoke disappears while iodine and malt takes over. It is a sweet biscuity maltiness. Then there are lemons. And the light smoke returns. Then more sweet maltiness. Engine oil and engine room. With a few drops of water: more lemon and malt. (89p)Initial TASTE: The arrival is slightly oily, then ginger, black pepper and salt.BODY: The oiliness enriches the body of this malt, which is quite sweet and rounded on the mid palate. Not very complex but really moreish and characterful. A little water doesn’t change much. (87p)FINISH: Black pepper, ginger, lemon (86p)= Weighted Rate 88 points

reviews.content: Honest, tasty, refreshing. Simple and good. Or is it more 'simply good'?
reviews.nose: Pleasantly spicy with a delicate herbal note. After a few moments, fresh citrus notes follow, slightly wet, almost a little musty wood, milk chocolate and slightly musty fruit notes. Becomes a little more tropical over time, goes towards pineapple and mango. Vanilla ice cream is also added. At first I was a little disappointed, but time and affection reveal great and quite distinct fruit notes. Sometimes maybe a tad too light-footed. Still really beautiful and even summery and refreshing.
reviews.taste: Delicious. Wonderful light fruity notes, very delicately spicy, here the lemonade that I really appreciate comes through quite well. Light wood, delicate tropical fruits, tangy citrus notes. With the second sip, the herbal notes are pushed into the foreground, the lemon turns into a sweet, juicy orange.
reviews.finish: Pleasantly dry, very slight tendency towards bitterness. It might be a bit flat, but it doesn't matter. A slight tart herb and wood note remains along with a hint of bitter lemon peel.

reviews.content: Like so many malts, better on the nose than the palate. Unlike so many other malts, it is quite characterful. Unfortunately I didn't often find myself reaching for that character. Water brings out a dirty/funkiness/mustiness. Will certainly buy another bottle, but might be a while.
reviews.nose: Automatic, floral, mineral, citrus rind, vanilla, sweet like honey.
reviews.taste: Initially quite delicious. Sweet, creamy, toffee, and custard. With time, becoming sharp and spicy. Best not to linger in the glass.
reviews.finish: Sweet and sharp/tart citrus, sour barley, becomes more sharp and bitter, somewhat numbing.

reviews.content: Best of bourbon influence. Sweet honey, caramel, chocolate light cereal notes. Very nice

This is a really impressive bottle for the price, simple but effective, not easily boring, both fresh and full of sweetness. The aromas really go hand in hand, an impressive harmony. An original herbal background structure reveals a beautiful and unique character. Budget friendly, whisky lover friendly, what more could you want! Price performance: Good-Very good Would I buy it again?: Yes!
reviews.nose: A nutty, dry woody side. Lots of honey coated cracker. A slightly waxy side but very light; beeswax. Floral and slightly grassy. Very light orange peel maybe. Lemon peel that becomes obvious over time. Nuts go beyond walnuts but they can't be distinguished exactly. Maybe hazelnut and almond. Grassy and floral combined, it reminds me of a yellow flower whose buds are consumed and whose exact name is unknown. Vanilla. Craterdi maltiness opens. Heather. Maybe green apple. Light caramel croquant. A very harmonic, homogeneous and characterful nose!
reviews.taste: On the palate, zero bitterness, very low pungency. A little below medium sweetness. Intense green apple and super honey cracker. A light creamy, creamy note complements these two notes wonderfully. Vanilla with light spices, oak spice. A nice medium body that can be said. It has a soft consistency; really easy to drink. A light waxy note here, hand in hand with the green apple. A few notes of light herbal thyme and a subtle grassiness. A really quality palate. Like a super apple and honey cookie. Very enjoyable.
reviews.finish: A small crescendo is felt. Slowly opening cracker-like, crunchy notes give way to vanilla. Green apples continue to exist with a slightly acidic structure. At the end of the finish, light grey black pepper and oak spice and maybe a very, very light cinnamon stick. Especially retronasally, apples and light acetone. Medium length and intensity. No defects; zero bitterness and burning.

reviews.content: Tried this Deanston again at a whisky tasting, and fortunately it hasn't gone down any alley; a very nice whisky!
reviews.nose: Floral aroma with plenty of vanilla (custard) and honey, hinting at crème brûlée, orange peel, plum, yellow apple, mint, and leather, with light rubbery notes. If left for a while, a hint of white pepper emerges.
reviews.taste: Strong spicy-malty aroma, creamy mouthfeel, again with lots of vanilla and a little lemon, caramel and oak, round taste, the pepperiness is a bit disturbing.
reviews.finish: Medium-long finish, relatively weak, but spicy and pleasant with lots of vanilla, leather (and that rubber again), you get the feeling there's a bit of sherry in there.

In addition, there is a very gentle pepper in the background which provides a nice variation
reviews.finish: Medium long, here the pepper comes out more but still very soft. In addition, there is a good bitterness of oak that is softened by wild honey
